I work with quite a lot of plastics, machining them. And ill tell you right now nylon is one of my least liked.
The chips are strings (uhmw and ultim do this as well, but nylon is much worse) that get wrapped in literally everything. It loves to melt itself into drill flutes and there bushings regardless of how much cutting oils or coolant you run. That includes hollow mills and bits that run coolant through the tooling. It also rolls burs and makes flashing and skirting hard to avoid.

someone would say user error or bad set ups/programming combination of whatever. But i have yet to see a run not need to be baby sited to a certain degree. FYI: I do some hobby 3D printing at home, and one thing that's important with Nylon is to dry the nylon at about 70°C for at least 12 hours (it needs several days, I find, in practice) before heating it to its melting point, or else it hydrolyzes and basically the plastic ends up brittle.

Nylon is hygroscopic and absorbs a significant fraction of its mass from the air in a matter of hours. If I see steam coming from the hot extruder, or the plastic forming bubbles from the expanding water vapour, it's a bad sign, and to avoid this I've found that it's best to keep the nylon in a dryer while the machine is printing.

You can buy filament dryers or use a good food dehydrator (one that heats recirculated air and not just outside air), but beware that some can't get the temperature higher than about 55°C, regardless of what's printed on the temperature dial. I use one that I've modified to use a more precise PID temperature controller, but that isn't strictly necessary.

A tangent on Nylon: I work with injection molded bonded magnets at my job. The majority uses Nylon12 binder, N6 is rare (has better mechanical properties but worse magnetic because it requires higher temperatures for molding). The rest is PPS, which is great because it has low CTE and chemical resistance but is worse magnetically because higher T needed for molding and more binder required (~40 vol% vs ~30% vol of PA12 and PA6)
